Changes Unknown when pulling **2efe7617a595b8ac6167db40724d9874afd6df23 on francesperry:master** into *\* on apache:master**.

OK, one more high-level comment that needs to be resolved before continuing.
I think representing every database row by a JdbcDataRecord will be inefficient, since every such object requires allocating 4 arrays, boxing the primitive-type columns into the Object[] array, etc. My experience with pumping a lot of data from/to a database says that these overheads can easily become a serious bottleneck.

I would recommend a slightly different approach that, e.g., Spring JDBC uses (RowMapper and BatchPreparedStatementSetter, see http://docs.spring.io/spring/docs/current/spring-framework-reference/html/jdbc.html): make this source and sink generic and let the user provide callbacks for extracting their type from a ResultSet/ResultSetMetadata, and for filling in a PreparedStatement from their type. I don't mean necessarily use Spring JDBC's classes directly (I don't know if we can or want to have that as a dependency, though if the answer was "yes" then it'd be nice)

Additionally, in the sink:
- for efficiency it'd be great to introduce batching.
- for both efficiency and generality, it'd be better to let the user supply a parameterized SQL string, rather than hand-assemble the string in the processElement call. It might be e.g. that the user wants to update() things rather than insert, or that they want to use a custom SQL dialect supported by their database of choice.

I'll also make a pass now over the code and comment on things that will likely stay relevant after such a refactoring.
Thanks for your comments. I will update the PR accordingly.

It's a bit puzzling to me that Lint complains about unused-variable, when in fact this is an unused-import (and I have annotated it as such). Perhaps the other annotation was confusing things.

Trying with just unused-import. If that doesn't work, I will use unused-variable.

Looking at other parts of the SDK, there seems to be a mix of 

# pylint: disable=wrong-import-order, wrong-import-position

# pylint: disable=unused-variable

I'm not sure why unused-variable is not part of the existing disables (and instead has its own entry).

I'm also not getting any complains regarding wrong-import-order/wrong-import-position which I would expect.

@chamikaramj What is the right thing to do here (should there be cleanups in the SDK regarding proper pylint usage; ie only have the pylint warning overrides that are needed and have them be uniform)?

Couldn't get things to work with 'unused-import' so going with 'unused-variable' to make lint happy.

The eclipse compiler spits out a ton of warnings as it doesn't have the -Xlint:-\* flags we use. (it ignores those flags)  Not a big deal.

Anyway, I believe this is ready to be merged.  Thanks!

I tried restoring one of the `package-info.java` files before running `mvn clean install -Peclipse-jdt` to verify failures, but the build succeeded. Can you confirm that this is validating what it should be? Are there any other steps needed?

I'm also wondering if this is the right direction-- do we need to support the eclipse compiler, or is it just as easy to configure the eclipse project to use one of the other supported JDK's? @dhalperi, has there been any previous discussion on which JDK's we support?
Thanks folks! Closing...

You cannot configure eclipse to COMPILE with anything other than it's compiler as the entire syntax highlighting and assist and stuff is done via hooks into their compiler.

In regards to the package-info, it won't be a problem outside of eclipse as the main code and the test code is compiled in two separate passes.  Within eclipse, everything is compiled in one pass and the error pops up.
The travis test_wordcount stuff is failing with the same error on master (after clean rebuild) on my machine so I don't think that has anything to do with my changes.

I'm a bit reluctant to do this more generally because for iterable side inputs, at least, we currently support potentially a large set of moderately sized elements.  The benefit we gain here from reshuffling is that we are able to reduce the read latency that comes from oversharding for a large collection of small elements [i.e. gcs paths](through prefetching and skipping empty shards).  But for a large collection of moderately sized elements, perhaps it's the case that this overhead is negligible and most of the time is spent actually reading the elements.  I don't have any numbers, but I could see adding an extra shuffle step here in this case to be somewhat costly because it bottlenecks on one worker.  What do you think?

LGTM

OK, let's just fix the finalization for now.
